text:
What happens now? A day after we vote out of the EU we look at the challenges ahead 12:15, 25 Jun 2016 Boris or Michael? Corbyn's future? What happens now the dust settles on our EU departure vote Shares Get daily news by email Mary Turner - WPA Pool/Getty Images Boris Johnson speaks following the results of the EU referendum 
It has been more than 24 hours since the North East - and Britain - voted to leave the EU - so what happens now and where do we go from here? 
With David Cameron packing his bags, the focus shifts onto new leadership and who will oversee our separation from Europe. Will it be Boris Johnson or Michael Gove? 
Jeremy Corbyn said on Saturday that those concerned about immigration must not be derided as “little Englanders” or “racists”. But what about his future? New leadership 
David Cameron announced he would step down in the autumn as he was not the right “captain to steer the country to its next destination”. 
So that means a new Conservative leader and prime minister is expected to be elected by the end of September. 
Conservative MPs would hold a series of ballots, with all but the two most popular candidates being eliminated. The final two will then go into a run-off in which all Conservative Party members will get a vote. 
With Boris Johnson and Michael Gove leading the party’s Brexit campaign - could they be our new leaders? Is Corbyn next to go? 
With Cameron gone, the pressure is now on Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn from inside his own party. 
Swathes of voters in Labour heartlands like Sunderland and parts of Tyneside voted against Mr Corbyn who was in favour of remaining in the EU. 
Two MPs have submitted a motion of no confidence in Mr Corbyn, accusing him of weak leadership during the referendum. 
This is not a formal mechanism for removing Mr Corbyn and he could survive even if the vote, should it take place, went against him. The Stock Market The 'Gherkin' and Canary Wharf at sunrise in the City of London 
Market reaction to the referendum result was immediate and dramatic. 
The FTSE 100 index of leading shares fell 8% after opening in London. There was a big sell-off of bank shares and housebuilders, with Barclays and RBS at one point down by more than 30%. By the end of trading, the index had bounced back, closing 2.8% down. The FTSE 250 index closed down 7%. 
The value of the pound has also been hit hard on the foreign exchange markets, tumbling to lows not seen since 1985. At one stage, it hit $1.3305, a fall of more than 10%, although it too slightly recovered to close down 9% at £1.36. How do we exit? 
In order to begin the separation from Europe there is a legal process, known as Article 50. 
Mr Cameron wants his successor to decide when to activate Article 50 by notifying the European Council. But Europe is more anxious to get the process moving as quickly as possible. 
Once this happens, the UK is cut out of EU decision-making at the highest level and there will be no way back unless by unanimous consent from all other member states. 
Quitting the EU is not an automatic process - it has to be negotiated with the remaining 27 members and ultimately approved by them by qualified majority. Next week Lauren Hurley/PA Wire Prime Minister David Cameron speaks outside 10 Downing Street, London, with wife Samantha where he announced his resignation after Britain voted to leave the European Union in an historic referendum which has thrown Westminster politics into disarray and sent the pound tumbling on the world markets. PRESS ASSOCIATION Photo. Picture date: Friday June 24, 2016. See PA story POLITICS EU. Photo credit should read: Lauren Hurley/PA Wire 
Monday will be a big day in Parliament. 
David Cameron will make a statement on the referendum expected to take place in the afternoon. 
The process of extricating the UK from the EU will ultimately involve rescinding the 1972 European Communities Act, the brief piece of legislation that brought the country into the European Economic Community, as it was then known, and which gives primacy to EU law in the UK. 
It will also mean sifting through an estimated 80,000 pages of EU agreements, which have been enacted over the past five decades, to decide which will be repealed, amended or retained. Boris and Michael Stefan Rousseau/PA Wire Michael Gove (left) and Boris Johnson hold a press conference at Brexit HQ in Westminster, London, after David Cameron has announced he will quit as Prime Minister 
So who is going to do all the negotiating on behalf of places like the North East? 
The current senior members of the Government were all in the “Remain” camp so many may head off to pastures new with Mr Cameron. 
It seems certain the next prime minister - whoever they may be - will take charge of the process. Could this be either Boris Johnson or Michael Gove? More on the EU Referendum
